My apologies for the long silence! I've had a jam-packed weekend so far. My teachers seem determined to test my knowledge, as I discovered I have around 20 tests on Tuesday! But, on a brighter note, we had marching band practice yesterday. It was a cool experience as we stayed indoors the entire time, and I got to play second part, making the musical portion rather straightforward.

I left marching at around 5:00 PM and then met up with my friends for dinner, a plan made before I knew about the extra marching practice. It was a fun celebration as it was Kelly's birthday! Afterwards, we headed to Kel's house for a sleepover, filled with exciting activities. Despite the sleepover, I surprisingly went to bed earlier than usual because I had to attend a Bar Mitzvah this morning. It was a pretty interesting event.

For my CR project, we need to visit two places of worship different from our own. Naturally, one will be a Jewish synagogue, and I'm leaning towards a mosque for my other visit, although my plans might change. This has been my only opportunity to write, but I must go now. Maybe I'll have time to write more later. 

Until next time, *Ya di amore!*"

It's later now, and my parents have found a "constructive" activity for me: cleaning. Grrr, why do they always resort to chores? It's so annoying! I was enjoying a peaceful moment, free from homework, listening to jazz, when suddenly, "Hey Catie, go clean!"  My usual response, "Yeah, sure, fine, I'll clean," escaped my lips. (Spoiler alert: I almost never actually do it.)

But this time, my mom came upstairs, her voice dripping with that guilt-inducing "momly" tone, and asked me nicely to clean.  So, I reluctantly trudged downstairs, gathered the necessary cleaning supplies, and tackled the bathroom. Bleh! Cleaning is my nemesis. 

Suddenly, a crazy plan popped into my head. I should become a gold digger, marry a wealthy guy, and hire a cleaning lady and a cook to make me peanut butter sandwiches all day long.  Then, when I become super fat and he wants a divorce, I'll be golden ‚Äì no prenuptial agreement means I'll get half his assets!

Of course, I'd need to become a witch first to make any guy, let alone a rich one, marry me. But now that I've shared my plan, I'll have to come up with a new one. Oh well.

Truth be told, I have nothing much to write about, but I'm not in the mood to chat with anyone.  I wish I could go to the park, my favorite place in the world. I'd bring my mini disc player, swing on the swings, and let my thoughts drift. It's a fantastic place to be alone and contemplate things ‚Äì except when those little kids come along and stare at me like I'm Frankenstein because I'm a "big kid" on a swing. They get terrified and avoid the other swing, which drives them crazy because I usually stay there for an hour or so.  I adore little kids; they make me laugh. :)

Well, I've probably bored you enough. I'll write more later. ~Ya di amore~

I've completely forgotten how to write normally!  Mrs. Kane's journalistic writing style has really messed me up.  I can't seem to shake the habit of questioning everything's objectivity.  It's so frustrating!

On a brighter note, I chatted with Bryan online about jazz. I'm trying my best to forgive Alstadt, even though his actions really bothered me. He never asked for my input, never consulted me, and didn't even bother to tell me anything!  I know forgiving is the right thing to do, so that's what I'll focus on.

This weekend has been surprisingly enjoyable. I feel much better, and all I did was read three books! They were all great, by the way. Last night, I watched "Pretty Woman." It was so sweet and almost made me want to become a prostitute looking for love‚Äîjust kidding! 

I came across this beautiful quote from 1 Corinthians 13:4-8: "Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud. It is not rude, it is not self-seeking. It is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs. Love does not delight in evil, but rejoices with the truth. It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres. Love never fails."  I love this quote; it's so profound and true.

Another inspiring quote I found today, although not from the Bible, is: "Be who you are and say what you feel, for those who mind don't matter and those who matter don't mind" -Dr. Seuss. It's fantastic!

Well, I must go finish my conversation with Bryan and get some sleep.  Sweet dreams! :)

The thrill of victory was supposed to be exhilarating, but instead, a strange emptiness lingered within me. I had snagged 5th chair in the band, even surpassing Dan ‚Äì a feat I used to dream of. Yet, the joy I expected was absent. His bewildered expression was a testament to my unexpected success, but it failed to ignite any spark within me.

Lately, a disconcerting funk had settled over me, as if a vital part of myself had gone missing. I felt like a chameleon, constantly shifting and adapting my personality to fit the company I kept. Kelly, with her unwavering presence in my life, was the one constant I knew I could rely on.  Our long-standing bond gave me unwavering faith that we would remain connected, no matter the distance.  

My other close friends, however, felt less certain. Kelly C., with her aspirations of becoming a famous clarinet player, seemed destined for a path vastly different from mine. Overwhelmed with these thoughts, I realized I needed to curb my anxieties.  I hadn't even considered the implications for my guy friends. The sheer volume of potential goodbyes threatened to consume me.

The outdoor setting wasn't ideal as our music was disrupted, and my hair, dress, and shoes ended up completely soaked. 

Despite the weather woes, the day took an unexpected turn for the better. Chris offered me a ride home, and after changing into dry clothes, we headed to Chipotle with Brandon and Bryan. This was my first time trying Chipotle, and I was pleasantly surprised by how delicious the food was! Though I couldn't finish it all.

Our food adventure continued at Coldstone, where I indulged in chocolate ice cream with gummy bears.  Chris and I then spent some time driving around and chatting before I headed home.

Now, back to reality. I'm supposed to be studying math, but who am I kidding?
